desc.size: Biennial herb, to 1 m tall. Plant erect, sometimes slightly branched.

part.partText: alternate, long-stalked, 3 - 6 cm long and wide, lower leaves kidney-shaped, others triangular, tip pointed, margins coarsely toothed. Having the odor of garlic when crushed.
in short, branched clusters (terminal), white or cream-colored, 5 - 7 mm long, 3 mm wide at apex. Petals 4, rounded at tip, narrow towards base. Stamens 6: 4 tall, 2 short.
a narrow pod, widely spreading, 4 - 6.5 cm long, 4-angled. Seeds black, 3 mm long, oblong, many, in a single row.

similarSpecies.comments: Alliaria petiolata is the only representative of the genus Alliaria in the Chicago Region. It is quite distinctive in appearance.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: This common weed spreads rapidly across vast areas of disturbed shaded ground, especially floodplains of streams. It also occurs in disturbed portions of moist woods and wood margins. It can become so abundant that it almost excludes the native vegetation.

notes.comments: Introduced from Europe and first documented in the United States in 1868 in New York. The European settlers probably brought it here for cooking purposes (the garlic-flavored leaves are edible). It spread rapidly, and is now known to inhabit 38 states and four Canadian provinces. Management information for this important weed can be found at the Global Invasive Species Database.

etymology.comments: Alliaria means “of the Allium family.” Allium comes from the Latin word for garlic. Petiolata means “furnished with a leaf stalk.”
